instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.I2C_BKLT: What is I2C_BKLT? I2C_BKLT is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
This 2017 MacBook Pro board came with a dark screen and liquid damage in the backlight circuity area. I found a shorted cap (<CAPACITOR>C4811</CAPACITOR>) which I replaced. The backlight came on for a few days, then died again. I've replaced <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and checked all resistors and traces in that area. Machine boots and backlight enable signal is present. Still no backlight.

Then I found that <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, which supplies <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>, has a low resistance to ground (95 ohms; 0.09 V in diode mode); a good board shows 5+ kohms on this rail. I'm having a hard time figuring out where this partial short is located, since injecting 5 V only gets 0.1 A flowing and nothing heats up. Any way to pinpoint the culprit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
If machine boots and have external video and USB activity, then must be a problem with internal video.
If gets image on internal LCD, then go straight to backlight circuit.
Check anything backlight related connected to <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> rail; remove one by one, until find the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Ok, I resolved the short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> by replacing <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> a second time (it now measures 0.43 V in diode mode. However, the backlight is still nonfunctional.

I verified that the machine boots and gets an image on internal and external display. <SIGNAL>BLKT_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.3 V but there is no output from <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> at all. The only other observation is that the SCL and SDA data line voltages drop from 5.1 to 4.5 V as soon as <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> turns on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
That may be sign of I2C bus activity; better to check with o-scope.
Check all resistors and traces connected to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
Post <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> voltages.

Did you try known good LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Yes, I'm using a known good display. There were burnt vias around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> pins 9 and 10 and I had to run wires from those pins to <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR>.
Below are the <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> voltages. 

<TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>:
pin 3: 12.6V
pin 4: 13.1V
pin 1,2,5,6: <2V

<CHIP>U8400</CHIP>:
pin 1,2: 0.3V 
pin 4: 0.0V
pin 5: 5.1V
pin 9,10: 13.1V
pin 11: 12.4V
pin 12: 0.0V
pin 15,16: 4.5V
pin 17: 3.3V
pin 18: 5.1V
pin 19: 0.2V
pin 21: 0.0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Backlight adjust is done through I2C bus (<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA lines); is not sufficient to get enable signal.
The information sends by PCH (PWM) passes through LCD T-CON before arriving to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> (after conversion to I2C).
You may have other traces, or components damaged around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.

Check if <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is present at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is 2.5V. 

My understanding of the PWM for these displays is limited. Can you explain the PCH - LCD - <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> connectivity some more? Is the LCD T-CON the board on the display itself? Does the PCH send info to the LCD via <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> and the LCD then sends info to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> on the <SIGNAL>I2C_BKLT</SIGNAL> data lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
I'm at a loss as to where else to look. Here's what I have:

I verified that <SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> are both connected to the T-CON board. 
Both data lines are pulsing (although at a higher frequency than on a known good board). 
I verified that <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> is between 2.5 and 3.3 V and connected to J8500.
I have tried 3 displays and 2 different display cables.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Then must be some traces, or other components affected by liquid on the backlight circuitry.
Leakage between backlight output to data lines is very dangerous.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message: How important is the sense resistor <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR>? That's where I had burnt traces. Under what <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR> conditions would <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> refuse to activate? How can I test it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Check continuity from <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR> to <CHIP>U5450</CHIP>.
Post <CAPACITOR>C5459</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message: <CHIP>U5450</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C5459</CAPACITOR> are NOSTUFF on this model.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR> must be 0 ohm then; direct trace on the board, I suppose.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight problem and low <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> resistance to ground
threads.message:
Yup, it is. I also replaced <RESISTOR>R8400</RESISTOR> to no effect.

I'm giving up on this board - sometime you just have to accept that a deep mystery remains.
